title-group.article-title: Shaul Harel Receives 2011 Arnold P. Gold Foundation Humanism in Medicine Award at the Child Neurology Society

article-meta.aff: Creighton University Medical Center, Omaha, NE, USA

author-notes.corresp: Roger A. Brumback, MD, Creighton University Medical Center, 601 North 30th Street, Omaha, NE 68131 Email: rogerbrumback@creighton.edu

body.p: As a part of its many programs to enhance humanism in medicine, 1 -3 the Arnold P. Gold Foundation has established an award to be given annually by the Child Neurology Society. The Arnold P. Gold Foundation Humanism in Medicine Award at the Child Neurology Society recognizes a practicing child neurologist or developmental pediatrician who has shown extraordinary humanism in his or her medical career. Criteria include: demonstrating established and ongoing contributions to humanism in medicine; demonstrating compassion and empathy in the delivery of patient care; showing respect for patients, families, and coworkers; demonstrating cultural sensitivity in working with patients and family members of diverse backgrounds; displaying effective, empathic communication and listening skills; understanding a patient’s need for interpretation of complex medical diagnoses and treatments and making an effort to ensure patient comprehension; comprehending and showing respect for the patient’s viewpoint; showing sensitivity to the patient’s psychological well-being and identifying emotional concerns of patients and family members; engendering trust and confidence; and displaying competence in scientific endeavors. The first recipient, in 2010, was Ruth D. Nass. On October 28, 2011, Professor Shaul Harel fittingly became the second recipient (Figures 1 and 2). Harel has been known as the “father of child neurology” in Israel, having achieved distinction not only for his outstanding clinical expertise but also for his extraordinary educational and administrative activities. He has accumulated numerous academic accolades throughout his illustrious career and has always embodied the ideals of humanism in his many accomplishments. 4 -6 More recently, he has been involved in honoring Andrée Geulen, the Belgium woman who saved his life and the lives of many other Jewish children from the horrors of the World War II Nazi genocide. 6,7 During a trip to Masada to see a performance by The Israel Opera, Harel was inspired to write a song titled “Mademoiselle” in tribute to Andrée Geulen, which was subsequently beautifully sung by Keren Hadar for a recording and music video (Figure 3). That music video, which was played for the 90th birthday celebration for Andrée Geulen, is now freely available on the Internet with subtitles in English (http://youtu.be/QR6PC74--1s) or French (http://youtu.be/6-xxsT3Yop8).

caption.p: Shaul Harel (left) with Arnold P. Gold (center) and N. Paul Rosman (right), who introduced Harel at the ceremony for the Arnold P. Gold Foundation Humanism in Medicine Award at the Child Neurology Society on October 28, 2011.
Shaul Harel holding his award plaque and standing next to his wife Dalia and in front of the poster describing his many career accomplishments.

Still images from the English-subtitled music video of the song “Mademoiselle” with lyrics by Dalia and Shaul Harel and Dan Almagor, music by Rafi Kadishzon, and sung by Keren Hadar. The still images in the left column show Shaul Harel in the control booth at the music studio monitoring the recording and Keren Hadar singing. The still images in the right column show Andrée Geulen. The music video is freely available on the Internet at http://youtu.be/QR6PC74--1s.
